qas.question: What are the closest relatives of the deinonychosaurs?
What are the closest relatives of flying theropods?
Dromaeosaurids and troodontids are members of what group?

context: The consensus view in contemporary paleontology is that the <a0_0>flying theropods<a0_0/>, or avialans, are the closest relatives of the <a1_0><a2_0>deinonychosaurs<a2_0/><a1_0/>, which include dromaeosaurids and troodontids. Together, these form a group called Paraves. Some basal members of this group, such as Microraptor, have features which may have enabled them to glide or fly. The most basal deinonychosaurs were very small. This evidence raises the possibility that the ancestor of all paravians may have been arboreal, have been able to glide, or both. Unlike Archaeopteryx and the non-avialan feathered dinosaurs, who primarily ate meat, recent studies suggest that the first avialans were omnivores.
